definition: to listen to information/to get the news/to believe what one hears
to listen/to hear/to obey/a can (loanword from English "tin")/classifier for canned beverages
smile (archaic)
(literary pronunciation, still advocated in Taiwan) to rule/to sentence/to allow
letter/mail/CL:封[feng1]/to trust/to believe/to profess faith in/truthful/confidence/trust/at will/at random
to take heed of idle chatter (idiom)

sentences.english: The quickest and simplest way to wreck any relationship is to listen to gossip.
sentences.chinese: 关联的最快最浅易的步骤就是听信谣言。

sentences.english: You don't have to swallow every dumbass thing they espouse.
sentences.chinese: 你可没必要听信任何他们支持的蠢事。

sentences.english: I gave my ear to what I now know was the malice of slander .
sentences.chinese: 我过去听信了谣言，现在我知道那是恶意中伤。

sentences.english: Is this because the majority just won't listen to reason?
sentences.chinese: 难道仅仅是因为大众不听信忠言？

sentences.english: McGraw-Hill completely fell for Irving's story.
sentences.chinese: 麦格劳希尔集团完全听信了欧文的故事。

sentences.english: Do not listen to this sophistry by vested interests.
sentences.chinese: 不要听信这些既得利益者的诡辩。

sentences.english: She believes any man on his bare word.
sentences.chinese: 她只凭说词就听信任何人。

sentences.english: Many voters tend to drink in a demagogue's brazen lies.
sentences.chinese: 许多选民都易于听信煽动者无耻的谎言。

sentences.english: The quickest and simplest way to wreck any relship is to listen to gossip.
sentences.chinese: 危机相关的最快最纯洁的格式就是听信谰言。

sentences.english: The quickest and simplist way to wreck any relationship is to listen to gossip.
sentences.chinese: 破坏关系最快最简单的方法是听信谣言。

sentences.english: Every flatterer lives at the expense of those who listen to him.
sentences.chinese: 阿舆奉承的人是靠听信谗言的人活命的。

sentences.english: He was young and highly suggestible.
sentences.chinese: 他年轻，很容易听信他人的。

sentences.english: Takeing charge of yourself involoves putting to rest some very prevalent myths.
sentences.chinese: 把握自己就不要听信某些流行的荒诞说法。

definition: to easily trust/gullible/naïve
to falsely believe/to be mislead/to fall for (a trick etc)
selective listening/to hear what one wants to hear
slander/slanderous report/calumny/false charge
to take sth to be true
one side of the story/one-sided statement
to entice/to lead astray
to advise/to urge/to exhort/exhortation/advice/CL:席[xi2]
to speak off the cuff/to casually opine
gossip/hearsay/rumor
to mislead the public with rumors (idiom)/to delude the people with lies
variant of 矇騙|蒙骗[meng1 pian4]
to hoodwink/to deceive/to dupe sb
to exhort/to admonish
graceful words, flowery speech (idiom); elegant but insincere words/cheating wheedling/dishonest rhetoric
lit. to turn to any doctor one can find when critically ill (idiom); fig. to try anyone or anything in a crisis
to defraud/to swindle
